title: Investors back CBA bonus variability
text:
This variability comes after the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority, which is currently reviewing its prudential standard on remuneration, warned bank boards it wants to see more management accountability for failings.

“APRA is proposing a more direct oversight role for boards and greater use of discretion to reduce remuneration outcomes," said Louise Davison, CEO of the Australian Council of Superannuation Investors.

"We support boards using downwards discretion as, historically, poor treatment of customers, regulatory breaches and conduct issues have had minimal impact on remuneration outcomes.

“There have been non-financial metrics in performance scorecards for a long-time. The issue is are they used in practice, and is there actually downside when things go wrong."

Other large companies are holding annual meetings this week. On Tuesday, Telstra director Craig Dunn is expected to face pressure given his previous role leading AMP. On Wednesday, Origin could face questions after activist group Market Forces called for its coal power station to be closed two years early.

Market Forces last week also stepped up pressure on Westpac, ANZ and National Australia Bank – which are facing second strikes at their annual general meetings later in the year – over lending to the coal sector.

'They read the room'

But the group will not be agitating against CBA after Ms Livingstone met with its executive director. The bank subsequently announced it would cease all lending to thermal coal mining and coal-fired power stations by 2030.

Advertisement

Having fended off the activists, Ms Livingstone was thoroughly prepared when addressing remuneration accountability concerns over the past month according to two CBA shareholders who met with her.

"Catherine was across all the details, she took us through the board risk committee processes and had all the data points going to the heart of issues,” said one. Another said: “They’ve read the room, and credit to them."

Institutional Shareholder Services (ISS), CGI Glass Lewis, Ownership Matters and ACSI are all understood to be advising votes in favour of the CBA remuneration report. Investors have also applauded the move to reduce short-term bonuses by 10 per cent as the bank continues to mop up after the damning APRA prudential inquiry and royal commission.

“All group executives experienced a reduction in their variable remuneration due to shareholder and customer outcomes, including as a consequence of the impact of customer remediation provisions on this year’s financial performance,” Ms Livingstone, who was paid $880,000 by CBA in the past year, told shareholders in a letter sent out ahead of the AGM.

Before CBA was hit with an historic 'first strike' at its AGM in 2016, the bank would almost always award all senior executives their full bonuses, regardless of whether problems had emerged during the year. For example, in the five financial years between 2012 and 2016, only four senior executives were paid below target, and the lowest of those was 94 per cent.

Shareholders want to see the newfound variability continue.

“Since 2016 the CBA board has demonstrated a significant degree of discipline in awarding [short term bonus] outcomes and this has continued into 2019,” said proxy advisory firm CGI Glass Lewis.

“We are encouraged by this discipline and hope to see variable pay being used as a mechanism to hold executives accountable in the future, in particular, beyond the current period of heightened scrutiny of Australia's financial services sector stemming from the royal commission.”

Advertisement

Shifting criteria

After APRA chairman Wayne Byres last week warned banks to suggest new models for pay, CBA has made a big shift towards non-financial metrics, and is already near APRA's proposal for financial performance measures to not comprise more than 50 per cent of performance criteria for variable remuneration outcomes.

ISS noted CBA had halved the proportion of executive short-term variable remuneration based on financial measures from 60 per cent to 30 per cent, a turnaround it described as "remarkable". The maximum variable remuneration outcomes for the CEO and most group executives are weighted at 55 per cent for financial measures and 45 per cent for non-financial measures. The shift comes after the Hayne royal commission found too much focus on financial measures were a cause of misconduct.

“Long-term investors support the inclusion of non-financial measures for executive remuneration. Like financial measures, they must be based on objective, transparent and measurable targets and be truly at-risk," Ms Davison said.

Yet some have raised concerns CBA's new short-term measures relate to efforts to fix the risk and governance failures of prior years. ISS said the "heavy emphasis on strategy is of concern to shareholders, as it appears to be rewarding the CEO and senior executives for fixing and attending to risk and governance issues that were identified in the royal commission and by the regulator, APRA".

“While this is necessary, shareholders may question the judgement of the board's knee-jerk reaction to reverse the emphasis away from financial to what many may consider to be non-financial 'day job' measures," ISS said.

David Higgins, chair of the CBA board 'people and remuneration committee' – who will be retiring from the board on Wednesday – said the bank will continue to "monitor and adjust our remuneration policy and frameworks for all employees so they continue to meet both the spirit and the requirement of revised regulatory standards and reflect evolving community expectations".

APRA is planning on releasing its new prudential standard CPS 511 on remuneration before the end of the year, with a three-month consultation period set to close on October 23.

APRA deputy chair John Lonsdale has said “remuneration and accountability frameworks play an important role in driving employee behaviour" and "where policies are poorly designed, or not followed in practice, companies may incentivise conduct that is contrary to the long-term interests of the company and its customers."
description: At its AGM on Wednesday, CBA's remuneration report is likely to win support after the bank curtailed the short-term bonuses of 14 senior executives.
